Advanced Installation Options
Driving &MiKTeXSetupWizard;
&MiKTeXSetupWizard; reads options from the file
setupwiz.opt
setup wizard setupwiz.opt
setupwiz.opt, if it exists.
It is also possible to specify options on the command-line, though this is a bit intricated. You have to stick to the following
setup wizard command-line options
syntax:
&setupexe; /C:"setupwiz --setup-path=""#e"" options"
Note that the placement of quotation marks is important, and that #e is surrounded with two pairs of double quotation marks.
For example, this command starts the wizard
unattended setup
setup wizard unattended mode
in unattended mode:
&prompt;&setupexe; /C:"setupwiz --setup-path=""#e"" --unattended" &prompt;
You can specify the following command-line options:
--allow-unattended-reboot
Restart the system, if necessary.
--common-config=dir
Set the location of the common configuration directory. This option requires administrative privileges.
--common-data=dir
Set the location of the common data directory. This option requires administrative privileges.
--download-only
Download all required packages, but do not otherwise install &MiKTeX;.
--dry-run
Simulate. No files shall be downloaded and/or installed.
--install-from-local-repository
Install &MiKTeX; from a directory.
--install-root=dir
Install &MiKTeX; in the specified directory.
--local-package-repository=dir
Download into (Install from) the specified directory.
--no-additional-roots
Do not integrate additional &TEXMF; root directories into the &MiKTeX; setup.
--private
Install &MiKTeX; for the
shared installation
current user only.
--program-folder=name
Add shortcuts to the specified program folder.
--remote-package-repository=url
Download from the specified the URL.
--roots=dirs
Register additional &TEXMF; root directories. dirs is a semicolon-separated list of fully qualified path names.
--shared
Install &MiKTeX; for everyone using this computer. This option
shared installation
requires administrative privileges.
--unattended
Run in unattended mode.
unattended setup
--user-config=dir
Set the location of the configuration directory for the current user.
--user-data=dir
Set the location of the data directory for the current user.

Directories
The standard installation procedure creates up to four directories:
The installation directory contains the installed files of the &MiKTeX; distribution.
installation directory defined
The default directory location is &installdir;.
The user configuration directory
user configuration directory defined
contains user-specific configuration files. The default directory location is &userconfigdir;.
The user data directory
user data directory defined
contains user-specific data files. The default directory location is &userdatadir;.
The common configuration & data directory
common configuration directory defined
common data directory defined
contains common configuration and data files. The default directory location is &commondatadir;.
It is possible to integrate additional directories into a &MiKTeX; setup. For example, users often want to maintain a separate directory with their own style files. See , for more information how to manage this.
Outline Fonts
Outline fonts psfonts.map
PostScript Type 1 fonts psfonts.map
Information about outline fonts is stored in a file by the name of psfonts.map. This file is created in the course of the setup/update process. It can be manually created by running
initexmf --mkmaps
psfonts.map creating
at the command prompt.
The contents of psfonts.map should never be edited: it will be overwritten by the &MiKTeX; update process.
psfonts.map depends on the file updmap.cfg. This configuration file contains declarative instructions (see ), which will be used to build psfonts.map.
Adding updmap.cfg Instructions
You must edit a local version of updmap.cfg, if you want to add instructions (e.g., add new map files entries).
Instructions in the local version of updmap.cfg take precedence over those specified in the main version, i.e., you can easily override options such as dvipsPreferOutline.
For example, follow these steps if you want to add an entry for the map file xyz.map:
Use the Explorer interface to open the directory miktex\config relative to the local &TEXMF; directory (see ).
Create a local version of updmap.cfg, if it doesn't yet exist: use the Explorer interface to create a new text document with the name of updmap.cfg.
Open updmap.cfg with Notepad.
Insert the following line: Map xyz.map
Save the file and exit Notepad.
Refresh the file name database (see .
Run initexmf --mkmaps to rebuild psfonts.map.

Package Management
package management
You use &MiKTeXPackageManager; (&MPM;) to install and remove packages.
What Is a Package?
package
package defined
A package is a collection of files that (together) implement a specific feature.
Working With the Package Manager
The package manager can be run in two modes: batch and windowed.
&MPM; runs in batch mode if you specify command-line options such as --install and --update (see for a list of available command-line options).
To start the package manager in windowed mode, click Start Programs &progfldr; MiKTeX Package Manager ). You will see a window similar to this:
Installing Packages
packages installing
You install packages
packages installing
as follows:
Select all wanted packages in the list view.
Click on + to install the packages.
For example: you want to install the &ConTeXt; package:
Locate and select the &ConTeXt; package in the list view, e.g., type the key sequence
C O N T .
You can now click + to install the package.
Searching Packages
Sometimes you don't know the name of a package, but you know the
packages searching for
name of a file that belongs to the wanted package. In this case, enter the file name information in the file name edit control. Note that the file name information can include wildcard characters (*?).
For example: you need to download the class file weekly.cls:
Enter weekly.cls in the file name edit control.
Click the Filter button.
The list view will be reduced to contain only the calendar package. Selecting calendar and pressing + will install the package.
Managing Format Files
Many programs can load internal data structures from so called format files. For example, &LaTeX; macros
format files defined
are stored in the file latex.efmt. This file is loaed by &eTeX;, when you start &latex;.
Refreshing Format Files
format files refreshing
The setup program has created standard format files in course of the installation process. You can refresh these format files in &MiKTeXOptions;:
Click
Start Programs &progfldr; MiKTeX Options .
The &MiKTeXOptions; window opens. Click Update Now to refresh the formal files.
Defining New Format Files
Defining new format files is a task for experienced &TeX; users.
format files defining new
&MiKTeXOptions; can assist you in defining a new format:
Click
Start Programs &progfldr; MiKTeX Options .
The &MiKTeXOptions; window opens.
Click on the TeX Formats tab. You are presented with a list of known &TeX; formats. To add an entry to this list, click New....
In the Format Definition dialog box, enter the following information:
Format name
The name of the format.
Compiler
The &TeX; compiler variant (engine) which creates the format file.
Input file
The name of the main input file.
Output file
The name of the format file.
Preloaded format
Optional: The name of another format, which must be loaded before the actual format file is created.
Descriptioin
A one-line comment which describes the new format.
A new application file with the name of the format will be installed in the &MiKTeX; bin directory. This application file serves as a short-cut for compiler "&format". For example, these two commands are equivalent:
latex sample2e etex "&latex" sample2e
